stimulusHtml:
A group of students are to perform an experiment to determine the radius, R, of an amusement park ride in a park, using only a scale that measures in newtons and a stopwatch. They are expected to find R by plotting their data in a graph. Neither the linear speed v at a distance R from the axis of rotation nor the rideâ€™s period of rotation, T, is known to the students before starting the experiment. Assume the ride quickly reaches a constant rate of rotation after it starts.

(a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the radius, R, of the ride. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a).
(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the radius, R, of the ride?
(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the radius, R, of the ride.

(e) Another group of students observes the ride both with and without people on it and notices that the ride rotates at the same constant speed in both cases. Is the angular momentum of the ride with people on it greater than, less than, or equal to the angular momentum of the ride without people on it?
